summary: The study utilized various biocatalytic methods, including photoredox catalysis and enzyme cloning, to produce enantiomers with high yields. Proteins were purified using nickel NTA columns.
key_claims: Enzymes were cloned from Nicotiana tabacum DBR (NtDBR), P. appendiculatum DBR 1 (PaDBR1), P. appendiculatum DBR 2 (PaDBR2), and A. thaliana DBR 1 (AtDBR1).
Protein expression was carried out in BL21(DE3) E. coli cultures.
Purification of DBR enzymes involved sonication, centrifugation, and nickel NTA column chromatography.

process_signals.name: protein_concentration
process_signals.context: determined by A280 with calculated extinction coefficients

_refs.title: Optical Rotation: [α] D 25 = +27.6 (c. 1.0, CHCl 3 ) [(S)-enantiomer based on known literature value for opposite (R)-enantiomer
Density-Functional Theory of Atoms and Molecules

_title: Catalytic promiscuity enabled by photoredox catalysis in nicotinamide-dependent oxidoreductases
_abstract: Unless otherwise noted, all chemicals and reagents for chemical reactions were obtained from commercial suppliers and used as received (Sigma-Aldrich and VWR). GDH-105 and KRED-P2-D03 were purchased from Codexis as cell free lysates and used as received. Silica gel chromatography purifications were carried out using AMD Silica Gel 60. 1 H-and 13 C-NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker UltraShield Plus (500 and 125 MHz, respectively) instrument, and are internally referenced to residual proton signals in CDCl 3 (7.26 ppm). Data for 1 H-NMR are reported as follows: chemical shift (δ ppm), multiplicity (s = singlet, brs = broad singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet, m = multiplet, dd = doublet of doublet, dt = doublet of triplet, ddd = doublet of doublet of doublet), coupling constant (Hz), and integration. Data for 13 C NMR are reported in terms of chemical shift relative to CDCl 3 (77 ppm). High-resolution mass spectra were obtained on an Agilent 6220 LC/MS with an electrospray
